Show map of Downtown PittsburghShow map of PennsylvaniaShow map of the United StatesShow all | PPG Paints Arena **PPG Paints Arena** is a multi-purpose indoor [arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena "Arena") in [Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh"), Pennsylvania, that serves as the home of the [Pittsburgh Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Penguins "Pittsburgh Penguins") of the [National Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") (NHL). It previously was the home of the [Pittsburgh Power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Power "Pittsburgh Power") of the [Arena Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football League") (AFL) from 2011 to 2014. Construction was completed on August 1, 2010,[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Architect_Predicts_Aug._1_Completion_of_Pittsburgh's_New_Arena-6) and the arena opened in time for the 2010–11 NHL season.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-lumps-7) It replaced the Penguins' former arena, [Civic Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_Arena_(Pittsburgh) "Civic Arena (Pittsburgh)") (formerly known as Mellon Arena), which was completed in 1961. A ceremonial ground-breaking was held on August 14, 2008. The arena is the first [Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design "Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design") (LEED) gold-certified arena in both the NHL and AFL.[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Consol_Energy_Center_Is_First_NHL_Arena_To_Achieve_LEED_Gold_Certification-8) Soon after the arena opened in 2010 it was named "Best New Major Concert Venue" in the [Pollstar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollstar "Pollstar") Concert Industry Awards and "Best NHL Arena" in the _Sports Business Journal_ reader poll.[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Consol_Energy_Center_Wins_Award-9)[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-10) The arena was originally named **Consol Energy Center** ( **CEC**) after [Consol Energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consol_Energy "Consol Energy") purchased the naming rights in December 2008. The current name comes from Pittsburgh-based [PPG Industries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Industries "PPG Industries"), who purchased naming rights in October 2016.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-PPG-11)[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-PPG_Trib-12) ## Planning and funding Soon after buying the Penguins in 1999, [Mario Lemieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario Lemieux") began exploring a replacement for [Pittsburgh Civic Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_Arena_(Pittsburgh) "Civic Arena (Pittsburgh)"), the oldest arena in the NHL (built in 1961).[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Nest-13) In an attempt not to use public funding, the Penguins filed for a slots license under the Pennsylvania Gaming Control Board. The Penguins were granted the license, though the decision of which casino company would receive approval was the Gaming Control Board's decision.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-NoBrain-14) The Lemieux Group reached an agreement with [Isle of Capri Casinos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isle_of_Capri_Casinos "Isle of Capri Casinos"), which offered to fully fund a US$290 million arena, if Capri could also construct a $500 million casino nearby.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-NoBrain-14) Other casinos, including [Majestic Star Casino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Majestic_Star_Casino,_LLC "The Majestic Star Casino, LLC") and [Forest City Enterprises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forest_City_Enterprises "Forest City Enterprises"), also agreed to partially contribute to the arena's funding.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-PITG_Wins_Slots_Casino_License_for_North_Side-15) On December 20, 2006, the Gaming Control Board awarded the license to Majestic Star Casino, who agreed to pay $7.5 million for the first 30 years,[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Analysts:_Isle_of_Capri_Favored_to_Win-16) in addition to the Penguins paying $4 million per year.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pa._Gaming_Board_Awards_5_Slots_Licenses_in_Historic_Session-17)[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-ToBreak-18) The casino experienced financial difficulty, which could have led to taxpayers financing the entire project. However, on August 14, 2008, the Pennsylvania Gaming Control Board selected [Neil Bluhm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Bluhm "Neil Bluhm") to take ownership of the casinos, which pulled the casinos out of risk of bankruptcy.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Casino_Project_Back_on_Track-19) The casino, now known as the [Rivers Casino](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rivers_Casino_(Pittsburgh) "Rivers Casino (Pittsburgh)"), eventually opened on August 9, 2009, in the North Side [Chateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chateau_(Pittsburgh) "Chateau (Pittsburgh)") neighborhood. [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Consol_Construction_July_2009.jpg/250px-Consol_Construction_July_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Construction_July_2009.jpg) The arena in July 2009 The arena's funding plan was agreed upon by Lemieux, Pittsburgh mayor [Luke Ravenstahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luke_Ravenstahl "Luke Ravenstahl"), and Pennsylvania governor [Ed Rendell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ed_Rendell "Ed Rendell") on March 13, 2007, after much negotiation.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-dealkeep-20) During negotiations, the Penguins explored moving the franchise to [Kansas City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City,_Missouri "Kansas City, Missouri") or [Las Vegas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Las_Vegas "Las Vegas") (the latter of which [received an NHL expansion team in 2017](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vegas_Golden_Knights "Vegas Golden Knights")); after the deal was made the Penguins agreed to stay in Pittsburgh for at least 30 more years.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-dealkeep-20) Lemieux later stated that relocating the franchise was never a possibility, but instead it was a negotiation tactic to help the team get funding for the arena from both state and local officials.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Countdown_to_2010;_Arena_Construction_Begins-21) The arena was originally scheduled to open for the 2009–10 NHL season; however, this was pushed back to the 2010–11 NHL season.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_to_Open_New_Arena_in_2010%E2%80%9311_Season-22)[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_Delay_Arena_Opening_Until_2010-23) The arena was expected to cost approximately $290 million, but rose to $321 million due to increased cost of steel and insurance.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Costrise-24)[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-CostRiseTri-25) The Penguins agreed to pay $3.8 million per year toward construction, with an additional $400,000 per year toward capital improvements.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-dealkeep-20) After $31 million cost rise, the Penguins pledged an additional $15.5 million, while the State and Sports and Exhibition Authority split the difference.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Costrise-24)[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-CostRiseTri-25) In September 2009, the State contributed an additional $5.08 million from the "Pennsylvania Gaming Economic Development and Tourism Fund" to cover a rising "interest on variable rate bonds".[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-erdley-26) ## Design and construction [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Consol_Energy_Center_May_2009.jpg/250px-Consol_Energy_Center_May_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center_May_2009.jpg) The arena in May 2009 [Populous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populous_(company) "Populous (company)"), designers of [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park") and [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field"), designed the building working with local architect Astorino to develop the construction documents, while the ICON Venue group and [Oxford Development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_Development "Oxford Development") oversaw the building of the arena.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_Choose_Firms_to_Create_New_Arena-27) More than a dozen buildings were razed in order to create room for the new arena.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-implosion-28) On April 8, 2008, Populous presented design renderings to the Pittsburgh City Planning Commission, receiving negative feedback.[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-lumps-7) Local architect Rob Pfaffmann went so far as to say, "If I put a [Home Depot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Home_Depot "The Home Depot") sign on that, it looks like a Home Depot."[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-lumps-7) Populous returned on May 6 with new plans, which were unanimously approved by the City Planning Commission.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Planners_Approve_Final_Design_for_Penguins'_Arena-29)[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-New_Arena_Plan_Approved_by_City_Planning_Commission-30) > "This is going to be, technologically, one of the most advanced buildings in the country." — [David Morehouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Morehouse "David Morehouse"), Penguins president[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Sneak-31) The Penguins have contacted the Pittsburgh Technology Council, which includes 1,400 businesses, in order to find new technologies to implement into the arena's design.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-The_future_is_Now_for_Technology_at_Penguins'_New_Arena-32) On demand replays from touch-screens will be available in luxury suites, while " [Yinz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yinz "Yinz") Cam"—a system developed by [Carnegie Mellon University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Mellon_University "Carnegie Mellon University") students—will allow any fans to view instant replays from multiple angles on their cell phones.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Sneak-31) The arena's capacity will be 18,087 for hockey, in honor of [Sidney Crosby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Crosby "Sidney Crosby")'s number _87_,[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Nest-13) and 19,000 for basketball games.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-GreatGround-33) The venue will hold 14,536 to 19,758 for concerts, depending on the layout. The venue will also include 1,950 club seats and 66 suites, in honor of [Mario Lemieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario Lemieux")'s number _66_.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-GreatGround-33) Ticket prices will range from $115,000 to $150,000 per season for luxury boxes to individual game tickets at $22.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguin_Hockey_Fans_Will_Sit_in_Lap_of_Luxury_in_New_CONSOL_Energy_Center-34) Ken Sawyer, Penguins' chief executive officer, asked that the interior be modeled after that of the venue then known as [Jobing.com Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jobing.com_Arena "Jobing.com Arena") in [Glendale, Arizona](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glendale,_Arizona "Glendale, Arizona").[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-JobSaw-35) "I was just taken aback by their seats," said Sawyer, "Even when I was up in a high level, I had a great view."[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-JobSaw-35) NHL Commissioner [Gary Bettman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Bettman "Gary Bettman") called the building "very well designed."[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Bett-36) Bettman liked the size of the concourses and the view offered of Pittsburgh's skyline.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Bett-36) [Mario Lemieux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mario_Lemieux "Mario Lemieux") along with officials from the [state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania") and [local](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh "Pittsburgh") governments ceremonially broke ground on a new hockey arena on August 14, 2008.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Government_Officials,_Penguins_Break_Ground_on_New_Multi-Purpose_Arena-37) Shovels, with shafts made from team captain Sidney Crosby's used [hockey sticks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hockey_stick "Hockey stick"), were used for the ground-breaking ceremony.[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Ground_Broken_for_Penguins'_New_Home-38)[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Government_Officials,_Penguins_Break_Ground_on_New_Multi-Purpose_Arena1-39) Erection of [structural steel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_steel "Structural steel") took place from January 2009[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-JobSaw-35) to August 2009.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Consol_Energy_Center_Will_Be_Topped_Off_on_Thursday-40) While the arena was under construction, the Penguins [won](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2009 Stanley Cup Finals") the [Stanley Cup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanley_Cup "Stanley Cup"), and brought the Cup to the arena's construction site on July 9, 2009, during the offseason.[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-41) The arena was originally named for [Consol Energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consol_Energy "Consol Energy"), the largest producer of [bituminous coal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bituminous_coal "Bituminous coal") in the United States,[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pens_Assign_Naming_Rights_to_Arena-42) which signed a 21-year agreement with the Penguins in December 2008.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-CONSOL_Energy_Acquires_Naming_Rights_to_New_Pittsburgh_Arena-43) Secondary sponsors of the arena are [PNC Wealth Management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Financial_Services "PNC Financial Services"), [UPMC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh_Medical_Center "University of Pittsburgh Medical Center"), [Verizon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verizon_Communications "Verizon Communications"), [American Eagle Outfitters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Eagle_Outfitters "American Eagle Outfitters"), and [Dick's Sporting Goods](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dick%27s_Sporting_Goods "Dick's Sporting Goods"), the last three being existing sponsors carrying over from the Civic Arena.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_Add_Five_New_Sponsors_for_Consol_Energy_Center-44) On October 4, 2016, [PPG Industries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Industries "PPG Industries") purchased the [naming rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naming_rights "Naming rights") from Consol as a result of Consol wanting to get out of the naming rights deal due to the company struggling financially as a result of [low energy prices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010s_oil_glut "2010s oil glut"). Consol, which is also planning on letting its naming rights deal for [Consol Energy Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consol_Energy_Park "Consol Energy Park") expire, will remain a corporate sponsor with the Penguins in a lesser role.[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-PPG-11)[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-PPG_Trib-12) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/PensArena.jpg/250px-PensArena.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PensArena.jpg) The arena with the Consol Energy Center name from 2010 to 2016 PPG Paints Arena is one of the only major sports venues whose [soft drink](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_drink "Soft drink") contract is not with [The Coca-Cola Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Coca-Cola_Company "The Coca-Cola Company") or [PepsiCo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PepsiCo "PepsiCo"). (Coca-Cola previously held the contract with Civic Arena.) Instead, [Dr Pepper Snapple Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dr_Pepper_Snapple_Group "Dr Pepper Snapple Group") holds a contract, and serves its own products such as [RC Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RC_Cola "RC Cola"), [Diet Rite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diet_Rite "Diet Rite"), [Cherikee Red](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cherikee_Red "Cherikee Red"), and [Sunkist Orange Soda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunkist_(soft_drink) "Sunkist (soft drink)"), in addition to its more popular brands such as [Dr Pepper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dr_Pepper "Dr Pepper"), [7 Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/7_Up "7 Up"), and [A&W Root Beer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A%26W_Root_Beer "A&W Root Beer") that are typically sold alongside [Coca-Cola](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coca-Cola "Coca-Cola") or [Pepsi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepsi "Pepsi") products in other venues. At the time of the arena's opening, [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field") sold Coca-Cola products and [PNC Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Park "PNC Park") sold Pepsi products, making Pittsburgh's three major sporting venues initially each selling different soft drinks. In 2012, Heinz Field joined PNC Park in pouring Pepsi products, breaking a 50-year commitment with Coca-Cola, while PNC Park switched to Coca-Cola products for 2014.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-45) The final years of the Civic Arena were without a pouring rights contract due to its impending demolition. In this time, Coca-Cola retained pouring rights in fountains (seemingly due to the cost of a large scale changeover) and Dr Pepper/7 Up products were exclusively sold in bottles. This is one of the few times that a venue this large has sold products from competing soft drink companies.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-consolenergycenter2-46) As with most other NHL arenas, the Penguins make use of a [goal horn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_horn#Use_in_sports "Air horn") whenever the team scores a goal at home. It is also played just before the beginning of a home game, and after the Penguins win. Their current goal horn, made by [Nathan Manufacturing, Inc.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathan_Manufacturing,_Inc. "Nathan Manufacturing, Inc.") and introduced in 2005 to coincide with the arrival of [Sidney Crosby](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidney_Crosby "Sidney Crosby") to the team, was brought over from the Civic Arena to the PPG Paints Arena after the Penguins closed the Civic Arena.[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-47)[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-48) ## Hockey ### Penguins [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Consol_Energy_Center_March_2010.jpg/250px-Consol_Energy_Center_March_2010.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center_March_2010.jpg) The western facade of the arena in March 2010 before it officially opened and its arena signage installed, with the Civic Arena reflected in its [curtain wall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtain_wall_(architecture) "Curtain wall (architecture)") window. Team owner Mario Lemieux and captain Sidney Crosby officially opened the new ice on July 27, 2010, the same day as the official press conference to announce the [2011 NHL Winter Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_NHL_Winter_Classic "2011 NHL Winter Classic") at [Heinz Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heinz_Field "Heinz Field"). The two skated for about five minutes before being joined on the ice by a group of young hockey fans all wearing Lemieux's #66 or Crosby's #87 jerseys.[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Lemieux_and_Crosby_Christen_CONSOL_Energy_Center_Ice_Surface-49) The Penguins opened the arena with a pre-season game on September 22, 2010, with a 5–1 win over the rival [Detroit Red Wings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Detroit_Red_Wings "Detroit Red Wings"). Penguins [forward](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_(ice_hockey) "Forward (ice hockey)") [Mike Comrie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Comrie "Mike Comrie") scored the first goal in the new arena, 81 seconds into the game.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_Open_Consol_Energy_Center_With_5%E2%80%931_Exhibition_Win-50) The team also added a third home pre-season game to the schedule. Team President David Morehouse said, "Our feeling is that more fans will want the chance to see and experience Consol Energy Center, so we thought it made sense to add the third preseason home game."[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pens_to_Open_New_Arena_With_Preseason_Game_vs._Detroit-51) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Consol_Energy_Center--indoors.jpg/250px-Consol_Energy_Center--indoors.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center--indoors.jpg) Inside PPG Paints Arena during a Penguins pre-season game in 2010. The Penguins officially opened the building on October 7, 2010, against their [cross-state rivals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flyers%E2%80%93Penguins_rivalry "Flyers–Penguins rivalry") [Philadelphia Flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Flyers "Philadelphia Flyers"), with the Penguins falling 3–2. The first goal was scored by the Flyers forward [Daniel Brière](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Bri%C3%A8re "Daniel Brière") at 2:51 in the 2nd period, a [power play](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_play_(sport) "Power play (sport)") goal. The first Penguin goal was scored by forward [Tyler Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyler_Kennedy "Tyler Kennedy") 44 seconds into the third period. The stars of the game were awarded to Kennedy, [Claude Giroux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Giroux "Claude Giroux") and Flyers rookie goaltender [Sergei Bobrovsky](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergei_Bobrovsky "Sergei Bobrovsky"), who made 29 of 31 saves in his NHL debut.[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Flyers_spoil_Penguins'_Debut_in_New_Home_With_3%E2%80%932_Win-52) The Penguins earned their first win at the arena on October 15, 2010, against the [New York Islanders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Islanders "New York Islanders"), prevailing on an overtime power-play goal by defenseman [Alex Goligoski](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Goligoski "Alex Goligoski"). It was also the first overtime game at the new arena. Goaltender [Brent Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brent_Johnson "Brent Johnson") earned the win for the Penguins, making 22 saves.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Penguins_3,_Islanders_2-53) The first playoff game in PPG Paints Arena was against the [Tampa Bay Lightning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Lightning "Tampa Bay Lightning") on April 13, 2011. The first playoff goal in the building was scored by [Alexei Kovalev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexei_Kovalev "Alexei Kovalev"). The Penguins would go on to win the first playoff game by a score of 3–0. [Marc-André Fleury](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marc-Andr%C3%A9_Fleury "Marc-André Fleury") had a 32-save shutout. The Penguins would go on to lose in seven games.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-nhl-54) During the 2011 off-season, 300 seats were added, increasing the hockey [seating capacity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seating_capacity "Seating capacity") from 18,087 to 18,387.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-add_seats-55) PPG Paints Arena hosted its first Stanley Cup Finals in [2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2016 Stanley Cup Finals"), which saw the Penguins defeat the [San Jose Sharks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose_Sharks "San Jose Sharks") in six games to clinch its fourth Cup. Although the Penguins clinched the Cup at the [SAP Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAP_Center "SAP Center") (home of the Sharks), PPG Paints did host a watch party for what turned out to be the series-clinching game, charging $10 for admission with all proceeds going to the Pittsburgh Penguins Foundation. Concessions and the team store were open, and the arena's goal horn played after every Penguins goal just like at a regular home game.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-56) The arena hosted a similar watch party [the following year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Stanley_Cup_Finals "2017 Stanley Cup Finals") for game six while the Penguins played the [Nashville Predators](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nashville_Predators "Nashville Predators") at [Bridgestone Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bridgestone_Arena "Bridgestone Arena"), which like the year before turned out to be the series-clinching game for the Penguins' fifth Cup.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-57) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Consol_Energy_Center_Panoramic2.jpg/960px-Consol_Energy_Center_Panoramic2.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Consol_Energy_Center_Panoramic2.jpg "Panorama view of the lower bowl of PPG Paints Arena before the first playoff game at the arena in 2011.") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/PPG_Paints_Arena_Scoreboard.jpg/250px-PPG_Paints_Arena_Scoreboard.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PPG_Paints_Arena_Scoreboard.jpg) The scoreboard of PPG Paints Arena in Pittsburgh, PA during a Penguins vs. Rangers game in 2019. ### Collegiate On July 13, 2010, the arena was selected to host the [2013 NCAA Frozen Four](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Ice_Hockey_Championship "NCAA Men's Ice Hockey Championship"), scheduled for April 11 and 13, 2013. The Penguins along with [Robert Morris University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Morris_Colonials_men%27s_ice_hockey "Robert Morris Colonials men's ice hockey") hosted the first NCAA Division I Men's Ice Hockey championship held in the state of [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"); the event also marked the first time that an NCAA championship game in a major team sport had been held in the city of Pittsburgh. "We are absolutely thrilled to have been chosen to host the 2013 Frozen Four at the (Consol Energy Center)," RMU head men's ice hockey coach [Derek Schooley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_Schooley "Derek Schooley") said. "The Frozen Four will be a major showcase for the city of Pittsburgh as well as our emerging hockey program. This is one of the NCAA's premier events, and Robert Morris and the city of Pittsburgh will be an excellent host."[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-NCAA_Awards_Frozen_Four_to_Pittsburgh_in_2013-58) In December 2012, the arena began hosting the [Three Rivers Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Rivers_Classic "Three Rivers Classic"), a two-day [Division I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I "NCAA Division I") college ice hockey tournament. Robert Morris won the first Classic title in a 1–0 win over Miami. The 2013 Classic featured Robert Morris and Penn State as the permanent fixtures, and also featured [Boston College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_College_Eagles_men%27s_ice_hockey "Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey") and [Bowling Green University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bowling_Green_Falcons_men%27s_ice_hockey "Bowling Green Falcons men's ice hockey"), with Boston College winning 8–2 over Penn State in the championship game. Meanwhile, teams such as [Michigan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michigan_Wolverines_men%27s_ice_hockey "Michigan Wolverines men's ice hockey") and [Minnesota](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minnesota_Golden_Gophers_men%27s_ice_hockey "Minnesota Golden Gophers men's ice hockey") are seen as potential participants for upcoming Classics.[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Molinari-59) The first collegiate event at PPG Paints Arena was the fifth-annual College Hockey Showcase on October 17, 2010, hosted by Robert Morris. In the event's first game the [Lady Colonials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Morris_Lady_Colonials_ice_hockey "Robert Morris Lady Colonials ice hockey") were defeated 4–3 by the [Northeastern Huskies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeastern_Huskies_women%27s_ice_hockey "Northeastern Huskies women's ice hockey"). The Colonials [ACHA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Collegiate_Hockey_Association "American Collegiate Hockey Association") club team beat [Pitt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Panthers "Pittsburgh Panthers") 6–4. In the arena's first NCAA men's game, the [Colonials men's team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Morris_Colonials_men%27s_ice_hockey "Robert Morris Colonials men's ice hockey") defeated [Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Falcons_men%27s_ice_hockey "Air Force Falcons men's ice hockey"), 3–2.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Robert_Morris_Hockey:_Colonials_Victorious_in_Consol_Debut-60) In conjunction with the [2011 NHL Winter Classic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_NHL_Winter_Classic "2011 NHL Winter Classic"), held on January 2 at nearby Heinz Field, a collegiate game and an [American Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Hockey_League "American Hockey League") (AHL) game were contested at PPG Paints Arena on December 30, 2010. The first game matched the [RIT Tigers men's ice hockey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RIT_Tigers_men%27s_ice_hockey "RIT Tigers men's ice hockey") team against the Robert Morris Colonials; RIT won 4–3. The second game matched the top-level affiliates of the two Winter Classic teams (the Penguins and the Washington Capitals), the [Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilkes-Barre/Scranton_Penguins "Wilkes-Barre/Scranton Penguins") and the [Hershey Bears](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hershey_Bears "Hershey Bears"); the Bears won 1–0. ### PWHL On March 17, 2024, the [PWHL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Professional_Women%27s_Hockey_League "Professional Women's Hockey League") played a one-off game between the [Toronto Sceptres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toronto_Sceptres "Toronto Sceptres") and the [Montréal Victorie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montreal_Victoire "Montreal Victoire") (both of which were unnamed at the time) in front of a crowd of 8,850 fans, making it the largest attended women's hockey game in Pittsburgh.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-61) ## Basketball Both the [University of Pittsburgh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Pittsburgh "University of Pittsburgh") and [Duquesne University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duquesne_University "Duquesne University") have dedicated locker rooms in the arena for use by the schools' basketball teams.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Pitt_Has_Own_Locker_Room_in_Consol_Energy_Center-62) Both schools made their first appearance on December 1, 2010, in the [City Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_Game "City Game"), the first ever basketball game hosted in the venue. Arena football [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg/250px-PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PPG_Paints_Arena_interior.jpg) An interior panorama of PPG Paints Arena in Pittsburgh, PA Shortly after PPG Paints was built, the [Arena Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football League") considered starting an expansion team in the arena,[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-AFL_Eyes_Pittsburgh_for_Possible_Expansion-68) but the league folded in August 2009.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-AFL_Appears_Close_to_Folding-69) However, after a [two-year hiatus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League#Canceled_2009_season/first_bankruptcy "Arena Football League"), the AFL returned and eyed an expansion team in Pittsburgh.[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-New_Arena_League_Reclaims_Old_Name,_Seeks_More_Teams-70) On August 19, 2010, news sources reported that PPG Paints Arena would be home to the [Pittsburgh Power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Power "Pittsburgh Power"), which began play in the spring of 2011. The team's ownership group includes former [Pittsburgh Steelers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and [Pro Football Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pro_Football_Hall_of_Fame "Pro Football Hall of Fame") member [Lynn Swann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lynn_Swann "Lynn Swann"). Pittsburgh was the 5th city added for the 2011 AFL season, joining the [San Jose SaberCats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Jose_SaberCats "San Jose SaberCats"), [Kansas City Command](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Command "Kansas City Command"), [New Orleans VooDoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Orleans_VooDoo "New Orleans VooDoo") and [Philadelphia Soul](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philadelphia_Soul "Philadelphia Soul") – who were all previous members of the [Arena Football League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arena_Football_League "Arena Football League").[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-Arena_Football_League_Coming_to_Pittsburgh-71) In nine home games, the Power averaged 9,197 fans per game, a figure that included an audience of 13,904 that showed up for the season opener against the Philadelphia Soul. Overall, the Power ranked sixth among the 18 Arena Football League teams in average attendance through 17 games that season, and its average attendance was about 1,000 people more than the AFL average.[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-pennsylvania-72) ## Gymnastics In 2016, the arena hosted the Kellogg's Tour of Gymnastics Champions.[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-73) ## Wrestling The 2019 NCAA Division I men's wrestling championship was held at the arena in March 2019.[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-74) ## Professional wrestling The arena has hosted various [WWE](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE "WWE") [pay-per-views and premium live events](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_WWE_pay-per-view_and_livestreaming_supercards "List of WWE pay-per-view and livestreaming supercards"), including [Royal Rumble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Rumble "Royal Rumble") in [2014](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Rumble_(2014) "Royal Rumble (2014)"), [Roadblock: End of the Line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roadblock:_End_of_the_Line "Roadblock: End of the Line") in 2016, [Extreme Rules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Extreme_Rules "WWE Extreme Rules") in [2018](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extreme_Rules_(2018) "Extreme Rules (2018)") and [Payback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Payback "WWE Payback") in [2023](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Payback_(2023) "Payback (2023)"). It has also hosted various _[Raw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Raw "WWE Raw")_ and _[SmackDown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_SmackDown "WWE SmackDown")_ TV shows. The arena planned to host _Raw_ on March 16, 2020, but on March 12, the show, along with all other WWE events at that time, were canceled and relocated to the [WWE Performance Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Performance_Center "WWE Performance Center") due to the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic").[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-75) ## Transportation access PPG Paints Arena is served by exits at Mile 1 of [Interstate 579](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_579 "Interstate 579") and exits 70A and 72B of [Interstate 376](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_376 "Interstate 376"); it is also within 1 mile of [Interstate 279](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_279 "Interstate 279"). Three blocks to the west of the center is the [Steel Plaza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steel_Plaza_(PAT_station) "Steel Plaza (PAT station)") transit station of the [Pittsburgh subway system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pittsburgh_Light_Rail "Pittsburgh Light Rail"). ## Events The arena opened on August 18, 2010, with a performance by [Paul McCartney](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_McCartney "Paul McCartney").[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PPG_Paints_Arena#cite_note-McCartney_to_Open_Consol_Energy_Center-76) The demand for the first show was so great that tickets sold out within five minutes of going on sale.
